titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:30. Tuesday. Having no conveniences for writing, I wasted the morning of this day. Called about eleven o’clock at Mr Trumbull’s house, and saw his picture of the declaration of independence, which is now nearly finished. I cannot say I was disappointed in the Execution of it, because my expectations were very low, but the picture is immeasurably below the dignity of the subject. It may be said of Trumbull’s talent, as the Spaniards say of heroes who were brave on a certain day— He has painted good pictures. I think the old smtall picture far superior to this large new one. He himself thinks otherwise. He has some Books on the President’s table, which the Abbe Correa, advised him to Letter on the backs—Locke, and Sidney— I told him I thought that was not the place for them— They were books for the members to read at home, but not to take with them there. I advised him to Letter them simply “Journals.” On returning to my lodgings I found there Mr R. King— I had written from Washington requesting him to call this day here, as I should not be able to visit him on Long Island. I had upwards of two hours conversation with him, on political affairs, and chiefly, on our Navigation Act of the last Session of Congress. I found he was averse to the renewal of our commercial Convention of 3 July 1815 with Great-Britain— His views with regard to the taking of Pensacola, and the proceedings in Florida coincided altogether with those which I had maintained— His son Charles, Mr and Mrs Trumbull, Mr Pitcairn and W. S. Clarkson also paid us visits— Dined with my wife and Mary Hellen, at Mr M’Cormick’s— Pitcairn, his nephew Brodie, and Clarkson were there. I received two Packets of despatches from the Department of State, with a Letter from the President, and the Letter to Aguirre altered and corrected from my draft. I sealed it and carried it myself to the Post-Office— Clarkson went with us this Evening to the Circus. The very worst exhibition of feats of Horsemanship that I ever saw. One of the Riders fell, and struck his head against the benches so that they apologized for his not appearing again. The still vaulting was not much better— We came home about eleven O’Clock.

2. VI: Met Chief Justice Isaac Parker of the Supreme Court of Massachusetts, this morning at the door of the City Hotel. He came by the Steam-Boats from Boston, to go up the Hudson river to Albany, and thence about thirty miles overland to Lenox in the County of Berkshire, where he is to hold a Court. At eight O’Clock we took the Steam-Boat, Connecticut, Captain Bunker for New-Haven—we found Mr Pitcairn on the wharf, to take leave of us— He gave me his metallic thermometer— In the boat I met among our fellow passengers, Judge William Johnson of the Supreme Court of the United States, with his Sister and daughter—and Mr Casaux, heretofore French Consul at Portsmouth, with his wife, a Lady from Boston— Judge Livingston also came on board and took leave of his Colleague.
The heat of the day was extreme; my thermometer nearly at 90. and all the morning a flat calm. We sat nevertheless an hour or two after dinner at table, conversing upon topics of literature, and the Arts. Judge Johnson I find is one of the anti-classical despisers of Homer and Virgil, and admirers of Ossian, Falconer, Walter Scott, Lord Byron, and Southey— He is a very ingenious and learned man and defends his opinions with so much earnestness, and vigour, that I found it advisable after some discussion to wave the subject; and left him philosophising with another of the Passengers, upon the construction of the Steam-Boat, and the conflicting pretensions of Fitch and Fulton. About eight in the Evening we reached the wharf at New-Haven; and transmigrated to the Fulton, Captain Law, in which we proceeded for Norwich. Judge Johnson and his family, and at least fifty other passengers left us, at New-Haven—thirty or forty others continued with us, and five or six came on board at New-Haven. It was near ten O’Clock when we left this place, continuing to plow the deep through the Night.

3. III. Although there is little motion in the Steam-Boats; and the accommodations for sleeping, are very good when the Boats are not over-crowded with Passengers, I have never been able to sleep much in them. I had a very good birth and bed, last Night, but awaked before three this morning, and mistaking the light of a lanthorn upon deck, reflected into the Cabin, for day light, rose and went upon deck, where for two hours and more my occupations consisted of Star-gazing, and conversing with a Baptist clergyman of dutch extraction, belonging to the interior of the State of New-York— He speaks English with a strong dutch accent, though he assures me that he himself and his father and mother were natives of this Country. He was much annoyed at a remark last Evening of Mr Casaux, that he thought the Spanish and Italian more melodious languages than the Dutch— The Sun rose as we were passing by the New-London Light-house— At New London Mr Stuart the British Consul there, landed: he had been one of our fellow passengers from New-York, and gave me an invitation to lodge at his house upon our return. We landed at Norwich between eight and nine O’Clock, and found Carriages on the wharf, ready to start with us. We engaged the Post-Coach for ourselves with Mr and Mrs Casaux. The other Passengers filled two more Stages— We dined at Plainfield, and at half-past four in the afternoon arrived at Chapotin’s, in Providence— The day was warm, and the Roads excessively dusty. The town seemed scarcely recovered from the frolic of Commencement, which was yesterday. In the Evening we all went to the Theatre where we saw a cure for the heart-ache and the forty thieves. It was near Midnight when we returned to our lodgings.

4. VI: At the common breakfast table this Morning, I met judge Howell, an old friend of my father’s, and once member of the old Continental Congress. We also met here again Mr Calhoun and Mr Price of Baltimore; engaged in their examination of manufactures. We parted from our other fellow travellers, Mr and Mrs Casaux, who were going to Boston, and took a return Boston Hack, to bring us directly to Quincy. We dined at Fuller’s tavern in Wrentham, and at Polley’s in Dedham I met Mr Russell’s son George; who has just entered the Sophomore Class at Providence, and was now going to Mr Barney Smith’s at Milton— Just at the setting of the Sun we arrived at my father’s house at Quincy, and found him alone at home. My Mother soon afterwards came in, with Louisa Smith, and Mrs Clarke, my late brother Charles’s eldest daughter. We were disappointed in the expectation of finding our sons here— George being absent on a visit to Salem; and John and Charles having returned at the close of their week’s vacation after Commencement to school at Boston.

5. VI:30. Day of repose. Walk with my father to his Salt marsh, where his workmen were digging ditches to drain off the Salt water brought by the tides— As we returned we stopped and visited Mrs Black, and Mrs Cruft who lodges at her house— Mrs Quincy, with her Son and daughter, and Mrs Cary paid a visit here. My Son George returned from his tour to Salem, this morning, and John and Charles walked out here from Boston this afternoon. Mr Tuckerman of Chelsea called early in the Evening. I took a second walk with my father after dinner— Mr and Mrs Cruft were also here this Evening.George 5 f. 8 i John 5 f 1½ i Charles 4 f 8 i.

6. VI: Attended Meeting, morning and afternoon, and heard Mr Tuckerman, who is a sensible man and a good preacher. So good that I reproach myself for the drowsiness which I found it almost impossible to resist, while hearing him. In the interval between the services, I examined my sons John and Charles, in Greek and Latin, to observe their proficiency. John has made good progress. Charles who is much fonder of books, yet advances slowly. Among the desires of my heart, the most deeply anxious is that for the good-conduct and welfare of my children. In them, my hopes and fears are most deeply involved— None of my children will probably ever answer to my hopes— May none of them ever realize my fears!— Mr Tuckerman and his son, a boy eight or nine years of age, dined with us at my father’s, and the afternoon and Evening were occupied with numerous visitors— Judge Tudor, with W. S. Shaw and De Grand from Boston, the three Messrs. Greenleaf’s, and R. G. Shaw with their ladies, Mrs Black, Mr and Mrs Quincy, Mr Marston his Sister and daughter, Captain Beale and his son George, Lucy Greenleaf, G. W. Apthorp and his wife, and some others. De Grand took my sons John and Charles with him into Boston— I engaged to dine with him next Tuesday week— My brother, who returned last evening from holding his Court at Barnstable, was also this day here.

7. VI: This was the first day since my arrival here that I found leisure for writing any thing; and far from improving it as I ought to have done, it was again almost entirely lost. Some of it was absorbed in examining my son George, in Greek and Latin— But in the forenoon I was called out to the visit of Mr and Mrs Whitney, and very soon after dinner to A. H. Everett and his brother John, who were soon followed by W. S. Shaw, with S. A. Welles and Mr Fisher, a brother of poor Fisher who died in Russia— They staid until after dark. Shaw brought me out three packets of despatches from Mr Bailey, in the Department of State— After an excessive and uninterrupted drought which has been prevailing here these two Months, there came on this afternoon a steady rain which continued the whole Evening.

8. V:30. I had intended, and promised to go in to Boston this Morning; but the storm continued through last Night, and the whole of this day, with scarcely one hour of intermission. It confined me to the house, and but for my natural infirmity, I might have employed it to useful purpose. About three hours of it were actually devoted towards redeeming the arrears of this journal, which at my departure from Washington had nearly run up to a week, and which during my journey had of course further increased. They are still a burthen upon my time— In vain I form the Resolution of retrieving them from day to day. My father’s library when I once come into it, holds out such a multitude of irresistible temptations to reading, which is a waste of time that they always break down my determination, and the day is gone leaving my proper work undone. My brother was here an hour this morning, and I devoted another hour to the examination of my Son George in Algebra— I also hunted up the first Volume of Gordon’s History of our revolutionary War, to examine a passage concerning the prosecution of J. Hancock, and his Sloop Liberty, for the use of my father— It engaged me in reading and thus consumed a considerable part of the day. My despatches remain unanswered, and partly unread.

9. VI: The storm continues night and day; again prevented me from going to Boston, and again kept me confined to the house— It is but this moment that I have brought up my arrears, at the approach of Evening; for having examined George in a passage of Plato’s Crito, and then referred to the Volume of the Bibliotheque des Philosophes, containing Dacier’s translation of it, I was allured by the Phedon which immediately succeeds and could not lay down the book until I had read it through. This delicious but unseasonable occupation, consumed the morning almost to the hour of dinner— If the study of Plato
were my proper business, I should be wasting my time with something else. The reflections that have occurred to me upon this perusal of the Phedon might be useful to me hereafter, if I had time to commit them to writing. The arguments of Socrates to prove the immortality of the Soul, are so weak that they hardly deserve the name of arguments. His principle that all things are generated by their contraries; that heat and cold, greatness and littleness, life and death produce each other, is an absurdity. His doctrine of innate ideas, of reminiscences and of abstract entities, is subtle but utterly groundless. One idea only appears to me to have weight that is the spiritual, simple, uncompounded nature of the Soul, and the inference from it that the Soul is therefore not subject to death— There is something very admirable in the composure, and tranquility with which he discourses at such a moment; but there is a want of sensibility in the coldness which he shews at parting from his wife and children. The objection taken by Sumunias, to the immortality of the Soul, that the Soul is a mere harmony resulting from the composition of the body, and its illustration, by comparison with the music produced by the Sound of a lyre, is so strong that Socrates by no means answers it— That of Cabes that the Soul is superior in excellence and duration to the body, and may outlast several bodies, as a man wears out several suits of Cloaths, but yet must finally perish, is equally weak, and indeed both sides of the argument appear to me to be so wretchedly managed, that as a logical controversy, it is scarcely worth reading— Yet it affords an inexhaustible fund for meditation— It gave me an ardent longing for leisure; which I should but too probably waste, if I had it— In the Evening I read part of a Dissertation upon the origin of the Constellations and of Fables, by Dupuis, in the fourth Volume of La Landes Astronomy. This also opened to me a new, and controvertible theory.

10. V: Read further in the Dissertation of Dupuis by morning Candle-light at the Office. Went into Boston with my wife. Mrs Clarke and Mary Hellen went with us, but returned to Quincy this Evening. Met at the Athenaeum Judge Davis and Jos. Hall—went with W. S. Shaw and engaged lodgings, at Mr Jones’s in Pearl Street, to come into Boston next Tuesday for the remainder of the week. I at first engaged them for this night; but we had stopped at Dr Welshs where they engaged us to dine and to lodge— I called at Mr Crufts’ but he was not at home. Went with W. S. Shaw, to Faneuil-Hall, and saw there the marble bust of my father which has within these few Months been placed there. They shewed me also the armory in the upper Story of the Hall, where the arms of the Boston Independent Military Companies are kept. I called at Waite’s printing Office, and made some arrangements with him respecting the printing of the Journals of the Convention which formed the Constitution of the United States, and the Secret Journals of the Old Continental Congress. After dinner I went again to the Athenaeum where I met Judge Davis, and Mr Johnson the Senator from Louisiana— We spent the Evening at Mr D. Sears’s, where there was a Ball, and where I met many of my friends and acquaintance— Mr Johnson of Louisiana Mr Williams, Senator U.S. from Mississippi and several other Strangers from the South were there. We returned between eleven and twelve at Night to Dr Welsh’s.

11. VI: I went immediately after rising this Morning, and called upon Mr Cruft, with whom I had a conversation concerning the management of my real Estate in Boston. I also called at Mr Jones’s in Pearl-Street for Shaw at James H. Foster’s, and at the Exchange Coffee House to see Mr Eustis, but he was not there—likewise at the Branch-Bank— Met several persons whom I knew, and with whom I stopped to speak—F. Amory, J. Townsend, R. Derby, and H. G. Otis, who told me he had called with a Mr Wilcocks of Philadelphia, at Dr Welsh’s to see me. On returning to Dr Welsh’s I found Wilcocks there— He had come since Tuesday from Philadelphia, and brought me Letters from C. J. Ingersoll at that place, and from Mr Calhoun the Secretary at War, at Washington, recommending the object of his Journey—which was to request that the frigate Macedonian, now ready to sail for the South-Sea might be ordered to go to California, there to reclaim a brother of Wilcocks and sundry other Americans who have been there imprisoned these nine Months, and to demand restoration of their vessel and Cargo which was seized and condemned at the same time— Mr Wilcocks said the Navy Agent Mr Binney informed him that the Macedonian was to sail the day after to-morrow Sunday. I told him that I could give no Orders to the Captain of the Macedonian, and he could any receive none from me. That
if any order could be given here, either to suspend her sailing, till further Instructions from the President could be received, or to vary her course as prescribed by her Sailing orders, it would come only from the Secretary of the Navy, Mr Crowinshield, now at Salem— That I believed the Captain of the Macedonian had a general order which would authorize him to apply for the liberation of American Citizens and the restoration of their property wherever there might be occasion for such interposition, as he had special orders to stop at Pernambuco for a similar purpose. I advised him therefore in the first instance to see Captain Downes, and ascertain whether he was not already sufficiently authorized to proceed to Calefornia, and interpose for the release of the party of Americans who are imprisoned there; and if not to go to Salem and apply to Mr Crowninshield for such an order. I gave him the letters to me from Calhoun, and Ingersoll, to shew to Crowninshield and authorized him to add that I would readily concur in any measure which he might think proper to take in the occasion— Before leaving Boston, I had visits from Mr Isaac Smith, J. Apthorp, and W. Foster junr— Mr Cruft and W. S. Shaw came out to Quincy with us, where there was a large party of Gentlemen at dinner. Messrs.Colman, (of Hingham) and Whitney— G. Apthorp, B. & G. Beale, Cruft, J. D. & P. Greenleaf, Linzee, Miller, Quincy and his Son, and R. G. & W. S. Shaw— Mr and Mrs W. Gray came out from Boston to visit us this afternoon. There was a Mr Turner also who came out before dinner and applied for the Consulate at Martinique, after having been disappointed, in applying for those of Amsterdam and Porto Rico— The first fire of the frigid season, I found this Morning at Mr Jones’s— Our sons John and Charles walked out this Evening from Boston, and came in after we were in bed.

12. V:My brother went to Boston, and my Son George went with him and to Cambridge— We had visitors from Boston, Mr Webster and G. Blake, and Powell Mason, with his Sister Mrs Grant. I sent to Boston a despatch for T. Sumter at Rio Janeiro, under cover to Captain Downes of the Macedonian frigate. I was very near being too late in sending this despatch, by my own negligence.— We all went to tea, and spent the Evening at Mr Quincy’s, where we met a small party from Boston— My brother & George came there on their return from Boston. Quincy walked home with me. I found two or three Packets of despatches from the Department of State, and a Letter from C. A. Rodney enclosing one to my father. There was a fire in the parlour, this Evening.— Salute from the Boston Light Infantry. Captain Codman.

13. V: I rise just at the dawn, and having not light enough for writing, continue reading the Dissertation of Dupuis in the fourth Volume of La Lande’s Astronomy, on the Origin of the Constellations and of the heathen Mythology, and when once I have entered upon it, I am occupied with it till breakfast time— I heard Mr Whitney, morning and afternoon; and the latter of his discourses upon 1. Corinthians XIV:40. Let all things be done with decency, and in order, contained lessons which if corrigible, I could not fail of taking to myself— Mr James Lovell of Boston came out, and paid me a visit. My Sons John and Charles, returned this Evening to Boston. With all the family except my father, I spent the Evening at my brother’s.

14. V:Mr Williams and Mr Johnson, members of the Senate of the United States, from the States of Mississippi, and of Louisiana, respectively, came out with W. S. Shaw and paid a visit to my father— They were here just at the time while the Quincy light Infantry Company Captain Thayer were manoeuvering before my father’s house in compliment to him. Shaw brought me out a large budget of despatches from the Department of State, which occupied me till dinner time. This afternoon I passed in writing, till towards its close, I walked an hour with George on the hills opposite my father’s house— Mrs T. B. Adams with her children Elizabeth, Abigail, and
Thomas, and Mrs Cruft spent the Evening with the Ladies at my father’s. My wife and George, entertained the Company with singing.

15. V: Wrote this morning a short Letter to D. Brent, and prepared several packets of despatches to be returned to the Department of State. Mr M’Guire called to see me— This Gentleman in the year 1805 came to me at Quincy, with a view of reading Law under my direction, but as I was not then in practice I declined taking him— He is a native of Maryland; but was educated at one of our Northern Colleges, and has married a grand daughter of Dr Sprague of Dedham, and has thus come into possession of an ample fortune— He qualified himself for practice as a lawyer, and was a short time in practice— He resided some time in his native State, and for the last three or four years at Dedham, for the benefit of his wife’s health. His project now is to purchase a farm in the immediate vicinity of Washington City, to the amount of 30 or 40,000 dollars, and he came to make numerous enquiries concerning the prices of Lands and other Circumstances in that Neighbourhood— I came with my family in to Boston— Walked with George, as far as Neponset Bridge, where the Carriage overtook us and, owing to the heat of the Sun, we rode the remainder of the way into town. We took lodgings at Mr Jones’s in Pearl Street. I dined with De Grand, and a company of more than twenty men, among whom B. Austin, N. Silsbee, Genl. Dearborn junr. Collector of the Port, Barney Smith, G. A. Otis and others. I promised Mr Silsbee that we would dine with him at Salem, next Monday— A number of De Grand’s friends came in successively after dinner— Mrs Adams, Mary Hellen and George dined at Dr Welsh’s— I found them there in the Evening and W. S. Shaw— I went with them, and Harriet Welsh, and our Sons John and Charles, to a puppet-show at Concert Hall, where we met Judge Davis, my Classmate Rand, B. Russell and H. G. Otis junr. There was a light thunder shower this Evening.

16. VI:Mr Cruft called upon me this Morning, and I walked with him, and viewed my houses at the corner of Nassau and Boylston Streets, and in Court Street— Met Mr W. Foster, and Jos: Head: and as we were returning home, Mr Bailey, who arrived the day before yesterday from Washington. After breakfast we called at the house of Mr Stewart the Painter’s and saw several Portraits upon which he is now engaged— As we came home my wife persuaded me to sit to Stewart for my own Picture, for my children. I returned to him, and engaged to sit, at seven O’Clock to morrow Morning. Mrs Adams and George, went to Cambridge. I received several visits—De Grand came with a Mr Cushing, who has heretofore cast Anchors for the public ships, and who complains that the Commissioners of the Navy now refuse to employ him, and have all the anchors cast at Washington, at double the cost of his charges— He gave me a statement of his prices, which I promised to make known, if a suitable opportunity should present itself, to the Commissioners of the Navy— A Mr Robert Stevens of Newport, Rhode Island, came to solicit the appointment of Consul at Genoa, for his Son, and brought a Letter, recommending him, from Mr Hunter the Rhode-Island Senator. We dined at Mr William Gray’s— My father and Mother and Louisa Smith were of the party. General Dearborn the elder and his Lady were there— All the rest of the company were of Mr Gray’s family. My father and mother returned to Quincy after dinner. Louisa Smith remained in town, and we spent the Evening at Dr Welsh’s— I called before dinner upon A. H. Everett, with whom I had a long conversation.

17. VI:30. Sat to Stewart from seven to nine O’Clock this Morning. Then received several visitors, among whom, Mr I. Thorndike. When I went to Russia in 1809 I was instructed to support a claim of his, upon the Russian Government, of indemnity for a vessel and Cargo belonging to him, taken by a Russian frigate in the Mediterranean in 1807. and condemned without a colour of reason. L. Harris had made a representation of the claim, to the Government, before I arrived there. I renewed it several times while I was there; it was afterwards again resumed by Harris, when he was Chargé d’Affaires, and lastly taken up by Mr Pinkney on his late Mission to Russia. No answer of any kind has been returned to any of these Notes, and Memorials, at which Mr Thorndike is
surprized and indignant— There is another case of a vessel belonging to the Weymouth commercial company, in precisely the same predicament— Mr Campbell has been instructed to renew the demand again, and Mr Thorndike enquired whether he could not be directed to present it to the Emperor in person— I satisfied him that this could not be done without inconvenience, and promised to notice the subject in correspondence with Mr Poletica, who is expected here shortly as Minister from Russia. I called at Waite the Printer’s, and made some further arrangements for printing the Journals of the federal Convention of 1787— Thence went to the Athenaeum where I received several despatches from Washington. Shaw went with me, and I called at B. Austin’s, but he was not at home. Mrs Jos. Hall received us. Mrs Adams and I dined at Mr H. G. Otis’s, with a company of twenty-five persons— Part of the Evening we spent at Dr Welsh’s— I made an arrangement this day, for using George’s Bedchamber as a writing room; having been hitherto unable to write at all, since we came in to Boston.

18. IV:30. Rose an hour before daylight, and waited for it in George’s chamber. Sat two hours to Stewart, with an interval of half an hour, when I returned home to breakfast. The remainder of the Morning was consumed in receiving visits. I called at the Athenaeum, and looked at the collection of my own books deposited there— We dined, including George, at Mr Gardner Greene’s, with nearly the same party that was yesterday at Mr Otis’s— There were besides, Mr and Mrs J. Hubbard, Mr and Mrs Jonathan Amory, and a Mr and Mrs Lenox of New-York, who are fellow lodgers with us at Mr Jones’s— We spent the Evening at Mrs J. Gore’s with a large party; among whom Mr & rs H. Lowndes of Charleston, Mr Williams the Senator from Mississippi, Mr and Mrs Hall, and many others.

19. VI: A continual storm of rain the whole day— I sat to Stewart, before and after breakfast; and found his conversation, as it has been at every sitting, very entertaining. His own figure is highly picturesque, with his dress always disordered, and taking snuff, from a large round tin wafer box, holding perhaps half a pound which he must use up in a day. He considers himself beyond all question the first portrait painter of the age, and tells numbers of anecdotes concerning himself to prove it, with the utmost simplicity, and unconsciousness of ridicule. His conclusion is not very wide from the truth— I had intended to pay visits this Morning, but was prevented by the weather. Melish Mott, and Lyon, two of George’s classmates came and dined with him, and after dinner Mott went out to Quincy with him. They are to be chambermates, at the University, the year that is now about commencing. Mott is from Charleston South Carolina, and his father was at Washington last Spring. I dined at G. Blake’s, with a company of 28 persons, among whom was the Governor of the Danish Island of St. Thomas. Mr Holley was there, and after dinner I became involved in a conversation with him upon religious topics, which almost became a controversy. The consequence was that the table-talk was almost engrossed by us, and the attention of the whole table was turned to us, much to my disadvantage, the topic being one upon which he was much more exercised and better prepared than I was. Mr Webster, Mr A. H. Everett, and one or two others occasionally relieved me by asking a question; but Holley was quite a match for us all— Mrs Adams spent the afternoon and Evening at Dr Welsh’s where I called for her. We came home between nine and ten.

20. VI: Breakfasted with P. P. F. de Grand, at his lodgings, and he discoursed with me much about the politics, and the state of parties in this Commonwealth. He wishes me to take some part or interest in them: but I see no object of public usefulness to be answered by it. He told me that Mr Monroe just before he made the appointment of Secretary of State, wrote a note to Judge Story, requesting to see him;
and when Story went to him, he said it had been his intention to appoint me Secretary of State; but Mr Clay had objected to the appointment, on the allegation that I was not a republican, and that Mr Crowninshield and Jonathan Russell had assured the President that it was so— I was not a republican. So it would seem that Story undertook to answer for my republicanism— Whether my appointment was for my own good or for that of my Country is known only to God. As yet I have far more reason to lament than to rejoice at the Event. Yet I feel not the less the obligation of Mr Monroe’s confidence in me, and the duty of personal devotion to the success of his administration which it imposes upon me— That Clay should have taken pains to prevent my appointment, is as natural as that he should have coveted it himself. Mr Crowninshield’s opposition to me arose no doubt from party, and Russell’s from personal motives. That Clay, should, have had the talent of making tools of those men for his purposes, is no mean proof of his address. His mind is of a very superior cast to their’s, but in his management of his opposition to me, there is a total disregard, not only of generosity, but of fairness. So painful however is the situation in which I am placed, that I wish every hour of my life, he had succeeded in keeping me from it— No more of this— George Blake came and took me to hear Mr Channing, who delivered a very good discourse upon the dangers of populous places to the purity of morals. We dined at our lodgings, and after dinner attended Mr Greenwood at Mr Parkman’s, a North-end Meeting House— Immediately after Meeting we proceeded to Salem, and took lodgings soon after Sunset, at the Essex Coffee-House, the house in which Mr W. Gray resided when he was an inhabitant of Salem, and which was built by him— We walked out in the Evening, and found the house of Mr Felt, who married Abigail Shaw; but they were not at home. We came over the Turnpike road— It was the first time I had been at Salem, since that road was constructed; or since the year 1791.

21. VI:Mr Felt came early this morning, and persuaded me to go and breakfast with him at his house Mrs. Adams was not well enough to go. Mary Hellen remained to breakfast with her; and Harriet Welsh, who came with us yesterday from Boston, also breakfasted with us at Felt’s. After breakfast he walked with me and we called at Mr Bentley’s— At his door we met Mr Crowninshield, and Mr Silsbee, who were coming to see me; they went into Bentley’s with us— He shewed us his cabinet of curiosities. Books, manuscripts, natural history, maps, pictures, engravings, a collection of all sorts of things, among which the greatest curiosities, are the coloured drawings from nature of insects, flowers, birds and beasts of a Miss Crowninshield, his adopted daughter, a young Lady educated entirely by himself, but possessing the most extraordinary talents. Her drawings are equal if not superior to any thing I ever saw of the same kind— We also saw her grandmother, an old Lady of the same name upwards of eighty years of age, and who keeps Mr Bentley’s house. Another of his curiosities, is a beautiful persian Manuscript of Sadi’s poems; an octavo Volume, with a number of illuminated allegorical pictures, representing emblems of human life and manners— Bentley himself is a very singular man; full of enthusiasm; inexhaustible in conversation—learned, honest, fanciful, deep in prejudices, and utterly destitute of discretion, a warm heart; a teeming brain, unable to controul either his likings or his dislikings; censuring without thought of giving offence; and the grossest of flatterers without meaning to flatter— In the course of the Morning I paid visits at Judge Story’s, and Mr B. Pickman’s, Mr Crowninshield’s and Mr Silsbee’s. I visited also the Salem Museum of Natural History, and the Athenaeum, where I found a valuable library and Mr Bowditch. I dined at Mr Silsbee’s with a company of twenty persons— Men, excepting Mrs Silsbee, and her Sister Mrs Crowninshield. Mrs Adams was ill with a severe sick head-ache, and dined at our lodgings. After dinner she went to Mrs Felt’s, where Harriet Welsh had dined. The dinner at Mr Silsbee’s was agreeable, and the conversation of Mr Bentley and Judge Story very animated— I left them just after six O’Clock; called at Mr Felt’s, where I found Mrs Adams, Harriet Welsh and Mary Hellen; we immediately returned to Boston, left Harriet Welsh at her father’s, and came to Mr Jones’s in Pearl Street, about half past nine— George came in soon after; but we were in bed— Mrs Adams still very unwell with her head-ache, and Mary Hellen sick, as she had been at intervals all the day. Harriet Welsh too had an inflammation on one of her feet, so that we returned from Salem, a travelling hospital. These circumstances allayed the pleasure of our excursion, which but for them would have been altogether agreeable.

22. VI: Morning call at Stewart’s. He had understood I should not come this Morning and had made another engagement, so that he could not take a sitting. I went with Shaw to Binon’s work shop. Binon is the French sculptor who made the marble bust of my father which is in Faneuil Hall. He is now at work upon a bust of Washington of the same size. The original from which he works, is a cast from the Bust of Houdon, taken from the life; incomparably the best likeness ever taken of Washington, and an admirable work of art. Mr Binon is spoiling his work, by departing from his original. He was not at his shop; having been confined there three weeks with an ague or abscess in the jaw. Shaw sent for him however, and he came— I shewed him where and how his likeness was defective, solely from his having varied from his original: he promised to return to it with all possible exactness— I called at W. Payne’s Office and took with him my certificates of State-Bank Stock, to the Bank, where I transferred it on the books, to be sold by him—$2700.— I met in the Street Mr Eustis and went with him to his lodgings at the Exchange Coffee-House— He has lately returned from his mission to the Netherlands, and from his conversation I discovered two things—one that he attributes the failure of the Commercial Negotiation in the Netherlands last year, to Mr Gallatin’s having been joined with him in it; and the other that he thought it not impossible that he himself might be sent to Europe again, to renew the Negotiation of that Treaty. He complains of his health but looks well, and says he is better than he was last year. He often draws a long breath, and complains of internal heat at the pit of the Stomach. He says he has consulted the most eminent physicians of the Netherlands, France and England, none of whom could tell him what was the cause of his disorder— I went out with James H. Foster, and dined at the Neponset Bridge Hotel, kept by T. Whitcomb, with the proprietors of the Corporation. Jos: Quincy, Captain B. Beale and his Son George, T. Greenleaf, G. W. Apthorp, Charles and Edward Miller, B. L. Guild and my brother. My father and Mr Whitney were invited guests— My brother came from holding his Court at Dedham and returned there this Evening— Mr Hedge the Professor and a Mr Clarke, called at the house on their return from Squantum to Cambridge, after dinner— We had a sumptuous entertainment. Whitcomb was with me in Europe, seven years from 1794 to 1801. His wife was with mine from our marriage in 1797. until we returned to this Country in 1801. and they were married at our house in Hanover Street in Boston in 1802. I saw Mrs Whitcomb this day after dinner— She was deeply affected, and wept profusely. I saw also three of their children: their eldest daughter Catherine and two boys— Returned with Mr Foster to Boston, and stopped at his house, where I saw his wife’s mother my Aunt Smith. She is nearly blind, and now upwards of 70 years of age. Yet she says she loves life as much as she ever did. I called at Dr Welsh’s, and afterwards at Mrs Dexter’s, the widow’s. Mrs Adams and George were there, spending the Evening. Mrs Dexter’s two daughters Mrs M’Kay and Mary Dexter were there— Her sons were both absent. About ten O’Clock we came home.

23. VI: I sat this morning to Stewart— He told me at first that he should want only four sittings from an hour and a half to two hours each. He has had four sittings of more than two hours each, and has not half finished the head. He says he is much satisfied with what he has done, but I cannot exactly say the same. From his house I went to the Albany Stage-Office, to enquire how the Stages travel thither; intending to return by that road to Washington. Thence I called at the Athenaeum, and was engaged there until one O’Clock. I was then going to the Common to attend the Review of the Boston Militia, by Brigadier General Sullivan, when I was informed it was too late the troops having been dismissed, and none upon the field. I had received a Card of invitation from General Sullivan to attend at the Review, and at the Tent where Refreshments were served. I was wrong in missing it, but the time passed insensibly by me— I dined with Shaw and George at Mr Mason’s— A company of twenty four persons, men and women. Mrs Adams had been paying visits all the morning, but was too unwell to go out to dinner— In the Evening
she was extremely ill. I had gone with Mr Holley from Mr Mason’s to the Wednesday Evening Club at Mr Frothingham’s, the second successor of Mr Emerson as Minister of the first Church. There I met Dr Dexter, Judges Dawes and Davis, Mr Welles, and Dr Spooner. When I came home I found my wife better, but still suffering with the headache— The state of her health gives me deep concern.

24. VI: Sat to Stewart. Wrote to D. Brent, and made up two packets of despatches to send to him. This was all I could do this Morning. Almost every day I receive a Letter from Mr Brent with all the important Letters and despatches received at the Department. Many of them urgently require that I should act upon them, but I find it utterly impossible. Every one of them is therefore a summons to me to return to my duty at Washington. I have now spent ten days in Boston in a perpetual course of visiting & banqueting and utter idleness. Should I pass a month longer here, it would slip away in the same manner. I can find no time to transact business of any sort— Not even to keep pace with time in my Journal. As my only resource I have therefore concluded to hasten my return to my Post, where at least some of my time will be devoted to the proper business of my life— Several visitors absorbed much of the Morning. Dined with Shaw, and George at Mr Thomas L. Winthrop’s. The company as usual at these dinners upwards of twenty. Mrs Adams continued so unwell that she sent an excuse, and dined at Dr Welsh’s— Our dinner at Mr Winthrop’s was longer than usual, and it was near eight when the Ladies left the table. I immediately followed them, and with George, went to Mr Jones’s, and took our baggage— Then to Dr Welsh’s where we took up my wife and Mary Hellen— We immediately came out to my father’s house at Quincy, and it being half past ten O’Clock when we arrived the family were all in bed, excepting Louisa Smith who opened the doors to us.

25. VI:30. The vacation after Commencement finishes this day, and my Son George returned to Cambridge. Although I have so much pressing business on my hands, I wasted the morning without writing—it was in Conversation with my father, for which I have only two or three days remaining, and which therefore I excused to myself as well as I could— Mr and Mrs Barney Smith from Milton, with a Mr and Miss De Wolf of Halifax Nova-Scotia paid visits here— After dinner I went with my wife and Louisa Smith to a tea-party at Mr Colman’s in Hingham— We went over the Bridge and Turnpike road which have been made since we went to Russia in 1809. It shortens the distance from my fathers house to Hingham from ten to five Miles. Mr and Mrs Whitney, Mr and Mrs Kimball with whom my Sons George and John lived when they were at the Hingham Academy, Mr Andrews Norton, and some of the Students with Mr Colman were there. We had conversations upon various subjects— Some of them of those in which Ladies take little satisfaction; topics of Religion and morality. Mr Colman is the Minister of Hingham, and the other Gentlemen there were clergymen— When we came home, we found that Mr Quincy had been here; and Mr Shaw, with Mr Ticknor from Boston— Shaw had asked me for a Letter of introduction for Mr Ticknor’s son to Mr Rush, which I had promised him; and I suppose they came out to ask for it— Shaw had told me it would be wanted before Sunday.

26. VI: A great part of this morning passed away like all the rest of the time since I have been here; in conversing with my father and in reading. My journal in the mean time has run up a week in arrear. Shall I never overcome this subtle thief of time procrastination? At last, little before Noon, finding the prospect inevitable of a large arrear at the moment of departing upon my return home which must of course accumulate during the Journey, and perhaps become irretrievable by the crowd of business which I must meet upon my return to Washington, I seriously began and wrote before and after dinner about five hours, upon this journal— Nothing else done, the whole day. My brother, with his wife, and youngest child were here. They had taken it to Milton, to consult Dr Holbrook, the child being ill with the Cholera— After they returned, he was worse and they send for the Doctor who called here on his return home— He brought with him a large white seed Cuccumber, from the seed sent last year by Mr Bentham to my father. Mr G. A. Otis, and Mr H. Smith, were also here this Morning. My sons John and George, were expected here to dinner, but only came out in the Evening. My wife is yet very unwell.

27. VI: Redeemed my arrears of Journal. Heard Mr Dean of Scituate. His morning text was from 1. Corinthians XII.13. “and have been all made to drink into one Spirit”— That of the afternoon from 1. Corinthians VI:11. “And such were some of you: but ye are washed, but ye are sanctified”— The doctrine of the morning discourse was that the object of all religions is the same; and that of the afternoon, the indispensible necessity of religion. His manner resembles much that of Doctor Kirkland, but with more animation— It is not generally pleasing. He is of the liberal Class, who consider religion as merely a system of morals. He and Mr Cruft from Boston dined with us at my father’s. I had intended to employ to some useful purpose the leisure of this day, but Mr De Grand came out from Boston, and spent the afternoon and Evening with me. We rambled over the hills together till Sunset, and then were tete a tete in the parlour till Suppertime— He supped with us, and then returned to Boston— My wife in the Evening took our Sons John and Charles to the South Boston Bridge, from which they walked home to Dr Welsh’s. She was afterwards again quite unwell.

28. VI: Went this Morning to my Brother’s House; and as he declines having any further management of my real Estate in Boston, I took the Deeds of my Houses in Nassau Street, Court-Street and Hancock Street in Boston, the three Policies of Insurance against Fire of the latter, 25 Shares, in the Middlesex Canal, and 12 in the Boylston Market Association— The management of this part of my affairs I shall commit to MrEdward Cruft, in Boston. I took also five Shares in the Boston Bank which I propose to sell— My brother and his wife dined with us at my fathers, and they gave me their Certificates of Stock in the Schuylkill Bridge Company, to be sold. My father and brother each 20 Shares, or 200 dollars Stock— At four this afternoon we took leave of my father and Mother, of Louisa Smith and Mrs Clarke, and my brother, and left Quincy upon our return to Washington— We stopp’d at the Hotel at Neponset Bridge, and saw Mrs Whitcomb; and as we came into town, again at Mrs Osborne’s— She was with us in Russia, as Martha Godfrey, and returned to this Country in the year 1815. with Mrs W. S. Smith. She soon after married Osborne a Musical Instrument-makers, and has now two boys, one 17 and the other 5 Months old, whom she shewed us with much pride— After setting down at Mr Jones’s in Pearl-street, we went and spent the Evening at Dr Welsh’s— Our Sons John and Charles are there.

29. VI:30. Visitors, from Breakfast time till near Noon— Artiguenave, who afterwards wrote me that he had something which he wished to disclose to me, and proposed to call upon me again at seven, to-morrow morning. Mr Waite, with whom I made some further arrangements for printing the Journals of the Convention, and the secret Journals of the old Congress— Mr Eustis, with whom I had a long Conversation upon public affairs and his own; and Mr Bailey, who took with him the manuscripts of the secret Journals, and Correspondence of the old Congress, to make the necessary arrangements for publication. He is to remain here until next Monday or Tuesday, after which, no further despatches from the Department of State addressed to me here are to be expected, and I authorized him to open those which may be received here after my departure. I sat to Stewart, but it was so much later than the hour I had appointed with him, that we were interrupted by other visitors at his rooms. I called at W. Payne and Co. Office, and left with Hall a small Certificate of Stock in the Boston Bank, to be sold with those in the State Bank, which I transferred last week. I went to the Stage-Office in Hanover Street; and engaged four Seats in the Mail Stage to Worcester for the day after to-morrow. They start at one O’Clock P.M. and will take us up at our lodgings. We dined at them this day— After dinner Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen went to Dr Welsh’s and I was engaged in writing till eight O’Clock, when I went to De Grand’s. He had assembled there a large party of Republicans, few of whom were personally known to me—B. Austin, J. Brazier, W. Little, Ballard one of the Editors of the Chronicle, and Orne, Editor of the Yankee were there, and W. Foster junr. who was not among friends.
There was no Conversation upon politics, but Artiguenave was there, and I told him I would either see him to-morrow Morning, or receive his communication this Evening. Finding I should walk home, he walked with me, and then made it. Artiguenave is a Frenchman, of respectable parentage, and good education, who as he says from an irresistible impulse, much against the will of his Parents went upon the Stage, and was one of the principal performers on the Theatre-Français— But being an ardent revolutionist and Napoleonite, on the late restoration of the Bourbons he abandoned the Stage and France, and came by the way of England here. He came to me in England, where I gave him some facility to procure his passage, which he could not else have effected, and he feels some obligation to me for this service. He teaches French here, and occasionally gives public readings of French Plays— He has been very successful and now proposes to settle here— By teaching French he has access to the principal families in Boston, and hears their Conversations— After some apologies, and some professions of honourable motives, he asked me, whether I thought Mr H. G. Otis was my friend? I told him—to a certain extent; but not to that of giving me a right to expect any important proof of his friendship. He said he was any thing but my friend— That he was burning with ambition for a foreign mission, and even now so impressed with the hope of receiving the appointment to France, that he had sent for him Artiguenave, to renew his French lessons to his daughter and told him, that it was in order that she might understand and speak French when they should arrive there, that he is so confident of receiving the appointment, that William Foster this very Evening at De Grand’s had told him he should very shortly go to France; for that Otis would certainly be appointed Minister there, and had promised him Foster the appointment of Secretary to the Legation— That with all this Confidence, Mr Otis had spoken to a friend of mine, whom he was not at liberty to name, with extreme contempt of the President, and with much rancour and fear of me— That he represented Mr Monroe as a weak man, influenced entirely by me. Yet he pretended to have been in great intimacy with the President at Washington last winter—that the President was entirely disposed to appoint him as Minister to France, but he was not sure of my concurrence and was afraid of opposition from me. He never spoke of me, but with ill-disguised bitterness. The friend of mine to whom he had alluded, was so disgusted with what Otis had said of me, that he had repeated it to Artiguenave with indignation; and although he could not repeat it to me himself, had given Artiguenave permission to tell me of it if he pleased. That Otis was so far persuaded of receiving the appointment to France, that he was in correspondence with Mr Hyde de Neuville on the subject, and within a few days had received a Letter from him giving him new encouragement to expect it— I told Artiguenave that I justly appreciated the motive of his communication— That Otis and I had many years been friends, as far as courtesy extended, and I had never been his enemy in any shape. But with many good and some brilliant qualities Mr Otis had always chosen to see in me a rival; and under constant social civilities and attentions, had never missed an opportunity of giving me a back-handed thrust—and as I never returned it, I had always been in the habit of receiving his good words and friendly courtesies—returning them when I could, and estimating them at precisely what they were worth— More than thirty years ago, at my very first outset in life, he had sped a dart at me— I very soon after knew that it was from his hand; but to this day he knows not that I ever made the discovery. He is now, precisely what he was then; and his great misfortune is that he cannot keep his own secret. The opinions he now gives out concerning Mr Monroe are utterly unfounded— Mr Monroe is neither a weak man, nor is he unduly influenced by me. As little is he disposed to give Mr Otis a Mission abroad, as Mr Otis was last winter in his intimacy— He has mistaken Mr Monroe’s civilities for Confidence. Artiguenave told me he had written to me more than three Months since on this subject—but the friend to whom he gave the letter did not go to Washington and returned him his Letter.

30. VI: Called at Mr Cruft’s and gave him my power of attorney for the management of my Real Estate in Boston. But the special powers to vote at the meetings of the proprietors of the Middlesex Canal, and of the Boston Market Association were not prepared— I sat to Stewart, two hours, but he could not finish, and asked me to give him another hour to-morrow Morning. My Mother came to town, and I went with her, my wife and Mary-Hellen to Cambridge, to my Son George’s chamber which is
number 11 Massachusetts Hall. His chamber-mate is Mellish Motte of Charleston South Carolina. We also saw the two Young Pope’s, nephews of Mr John Pope of Frankfort, Kentucky. I went over to Dr Waterhouse’s, and he returned with me to the College— We found the Ladies in the Carriage, returned from Mrs Gilman’s, and I immediately came with them back to Boston. George came with us— I made my necessary arrangements at the Branch-Bank, where Mr John Parker one of the Directors spoke to me of the condition of that Institution, and the necessity there would be that it should be patronised by the Government of the United States. I dined with R. G. Amory and a party of men. W. Tudor, J. Parker—Chief Justice—Isaac Parker, Jos: Hall, T. Dawes, John Phillips, A. Ritchie, Freeman, who married Amory’s daughter and some others. From Amory’s I went to the Wednesday Evening club at Dr Spooner’s, where the party was small. Called at Dr Welsh’s but my mother had returned to Quincy, and my family to our lodgings— My brother was also this day in town, but I missed of seeing him; and am deeply concerned for him and his family.

Day. Nothing regular during this Month. My hopes of finding during my excursion from Washington, some leisure hours for attention to business of my Office have been totally disappointed. It has been a time of total dissipation, accompanied with a continual sense of uneasiness that it was so wasted. I have indeed scarcely been able to keep my Journal current with the passage of time.
